diagnosis.clinicalPresentation: Generalized erythroderma (>80% BSA), severe pruritus, lymphadenopathy, significant circulating Sézary cells.
diagnosis.priorTreatmentSummary: Progressive disease despite Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) and Bexarotene.
diagnosis.reasonForCurrentTreatment: Progressive erythrodermic disease refractory to prior systemic/skin-directed therapy. TSEBT used for rapid disease debulking and symptom control.

treatmentPlan.rtRxDetails: 12 Gy in 12 fractions (1 Gy/fx, 3x/week over 4 weeks)
treatmentPlan.adjuvantSystemicTherapy: Plan to resume/initiate new systemic therapy (e.g., Mogamulizumab) post-TSEBT based on response.
medications: Systemic agents for pruritus (e.g., Gabapentin, Mirtazapine)
Antibiotics PRN for skin infections (high risk with erythroderma)

ctSimulation.setupInstructions: Clinical simulation for TSEBT. Patient stands on a rotating platform at an extended distance from the machine. Patient holds various positions to expose all skin surfaces for the 6 dual fields (AP/PA, obliques).
ctSimulation.referenceMarks: N/A (alignment is to room lasers and patient position, not tattoos).
ctSimulation.ctNotes: Patient measured for dose calculations. Setup confirmed. In-vivo dosimetry (TLD/OSLD) placement locations determined to verify dose during treatment. Shielding for eyes and nails designed.

dosimetry.gantryAngles: Specific TSEBT angles (dual fields from two gantry angles)
dosimetry.planNotes: Low dose TSEBT, 3x/week schedule, for palliative debulking.

fractions.setupNotes: Patient setup in all 6 positions. Shields in place. TLDs placed for dose check.
fractions.sideEffects: Skin remains erythematous, starting to show early desquamation. Pruritus slightly better.
fractions.notes: Patient reports significant fatigue but is tolerating the setup.

fractions.sideEffects: Moderate desquamation. Erythema persistent but less intense. Pruritus significantly improved.
fractions.notes: Completed final fraction of low-dose TSEBT. Continue intensive skin care.

reportDetails.specimen: Skin Punch Biopsy, Erythrodermic Skin, Back
reportDetails.diagnosis: CUTANEOUS T-CELL LYMPHOMA, CONSISTENT WITH SÉZARY SYNDROME (correlate with clinical and hematologic findings).
reportDetails.microscopicDescription: Sections show moderately dense superficial dermal lymphocytic infiltrate with prominent epidermotropism, including numerous single atypical lymphocytes and small Pautrier's microabscesses. The lymphocytes are small to medium-sized with markedly convoluted nuclei. Dermal fibrosis is minimal.
reportDetails.comment: Findings are compatible with cutaneous involvement by Sézary Syndrome. Correlation with peripheral blood flow cytometry and TCR gene rearrangement studies is recommended.

reportDetails.fullSummary: Photographs document diffuse, generalized erythroderma involving >80% of body surface area. Significant scaling and lichenification present. Excoriations noted secondary to severe pruritus.

imagingAndReports.summary: Mild generalized lymphadenopathy, stable from prior. No visceral involvement.

reportDetails.findings: Mildly prominent but subcentimeter lymph nodes noted in axillary, inguinal, and retroperitoneal regions, likely reactive/dermatopathic given clinical context, stable from prior exam. No hepatosplenomegaly. No suspicious visceral lesions.
reportDetails.impression: Mild generalized lymphadenopathy, likely reactive. No definitive evidence of visceral metastatic disease.

imagingAndReports.summary: Patient measured, setup confirmed for 6-field technique. Low-dose protocol planned.

reportDetails.procedure: Simulation for Low-Dose Total Skin Electron Beam Therapy.
reportDetails.setup: Patient positioned standing using Stanford technique setup (6 dual fields). Patient required frequent breaks due to fatigue but setup achieved.
reportDetails.dosimetry: Plan calculated for 12 Gy total dose delivered in 12 fractions (1 Gy/fx) over 4 weeks (3 fx/week). In-vivo dosimetry planned.
reportDetails.shielding: Custom eye shields, nail shields prepared.
reportDetails.notes: Patient educated on low-dose schedule and importance of skin care, especially given erythroderma. Procedure explained.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Emily White (Heme/Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Pt with known SS, progressive erythroderma and worsening pruritus despite ECP + Bexarotene. Discussed further options including other systemic agents vs TSEBT for rapid debulking/symptom control. Refer to Rad Onc for TSEBT consult.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Samuel Green (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Pt referred for TSEBT for refractory Stage IVA1 SS. Exam confirms T4 erythroderma. Discussed low-dose TSEBT (12 Gy) for palliation and debulking prior to potentially starting new systemic agent. Explained procedure, high risk of skin toxicity/infection in erythrodermic state, need for intensive skin care. Pt understands and wishes to proceed. Sim scheduled.

progressNotes.author: Nursing/RT Ed
progressNotes.summary: Emphasis on skin care (moisturizers, gentle cleansing, bleach baths if recommended), infection prevention, managing fatigue. Schedule reviewed.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Samuel Green (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Completed 6/12 fx. Skin remains erythematous, starting to show early desquamation. Pruritus slightly better. Tolerating daily setup. Continue low-dose TSEBT. Monitor closely for infection.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Samuel Green (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Completed 12/12 fx low-dose TSEBT. Moderate desquamation, particularly in folds. Erythema persistent but less intense. Pruritus significantly improved. Plan for continued intensive skin care. Follow up with Heme/Onc to discuss next systemic therapy.

patientEducation.goalsDiscussed: Palliative treatment to reduce the total amount of lymphoma in the body (debulking), control the severe skin redness and scaling (erythroderma), and improve itching.
patientEducation.sideEffectsReviewed: A significant, whole-body skin reaction, even with low dose. This includes redness, dryness, and peeling. Risk of skin infection is high due to pre-existing erythroderma. Fatigue is expected. Hair thinning/loss and nail changes are possible but may be less severe than with standard dose.
patientEducation.safetyConsiderations: Aggressive, gentle skin care (frequent moisturizing, avoiding irritants) is critical. Reporting any signs of skin infection (fever, pus, increased pain) immediately is essential.
patientEducation.patientResponsibilities: Attend all treatments (3x/week for 4 weeks). Adhere strictly to the skin care regimen. Monitor for infection.
patientEducation.medicationCompliance: Use supportive medications for itching and skin care as prescribed.
